document_title: Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD): Symptoms and causes
subsection_content:
Generalized anxiety disorder is often treated with psychological therapy (psychotherapy), medication, or a combination of both.
Psychotherapy (or talk therapy) is a term that refers to treatment techniques that help patients identify and change unhealthy emotions, thoughts, and behaviors.
1. Antidepressants
Medications prescribed to treat generalized anxiety disorder include:
Antidepressants: selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) antidepressants. It may take several weeks for the patient to start working again. In addition, some other medications include escitalopram (Lexapro), duloxetine (Cymbalta), venlafaxine (Effexor XR) and paroxetine (Paxil, Pexeva).; Anti-anxiety medications: Benzodiazepines are anti-anxiety sedatives that can help control severe forms of GAD. The medicine is effective in reducing anxiety quickly. Additionally, Buspirone is another anti-anxiety medication that may help treat GAD. Buspirone takes 3 – 4 weeks to be fully effective.
2. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT)
Doctors and psychologists often use cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) to treat generalized anxiety disorder. During CBT therapy, your doctor will examine your thoughts and feelings and help you recognize your excessive anxiety. Through cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), patients can eliminate negative thoughts and behaviors and learn to adopt healthier habits, lifestyles, and thoughts.
